title: Hays to profit from boom in British office jobs
text:

Sat, Aug 22, 2015, 18:21 BST - UK Markets closed Hays to profit from boom in British office jobs By Marion Dakers | Telegraph – 20 minutes ago -8.859 
Recruitment firm is set to post a double-digit rise in earnings 
Britain's booming jobs market has delivered a bumper year for the white collar recruitment firm Hays (LSE: HAS.L - news ) , as its fees come close to returning to levels seen before the recession. 
The company, one of the country’s biggest recruiters, is expected to post a 6pc rise in net fees to £768.6m on Thursday, and an 18pc rise in annual operating profits to £165.9m, according to a poll of analysts. 
Hays, which makes about a third of its fees in the UK and Ireland (Other OTC: IRLD - news ) , said last month that it had placed 14pc more workers into permanent professional roles in the three months to the end of June compared to last year, outpacing a 7pc rise in temporary staffing. * Jobs growth shows recovery is taking hold, says Hays * Questor share tip: Productivity the key to Hays profit leap * UK unemployment rises as wage growth suffers shock slowdown The growth in permanent jobs underlines the strengthening recovery in the jobs market. Between 2008 and late 2013, Hays reported a better performance in its British temporary staffing business than in permanent jobs, as companies shied away from major spending commitments. 
According to figures from UBS (NYSEArca: FBGX - news ) , job vacancies have been increasing by 20pc on last year’s levels since September, with both temporary and permanent roles on the rise. The British jobs market has been growing faster than France, Germany and Australia. 
Official figures showed that 354,000 more people were in work by the end of June compared to a year ago, although the overall number of workers fell slightly from record levels to 31.03m people. 
Even Hays’ City of London (LSE: CIN.L - news ) office has returned to growth in recent quarters, after several lean years following the financial crisis. Overall fees have surpassed the levels seen before the recession, while profits have yet to recover the lost ground. 
Panmure Gordon analysts said last week that staffing firms in many sectors were enjoying “a Goldilocks moment” as buoyant consumer confidence encourages more workers to switch jobs. 
Hays’ results came weeks after rival professional staffing firm Robert Walters (LSE: RWA.L - news ) reported a 74pc increase in half-year profits, driven by a 20pc rise in UK fees. Michael Page beat forecasts earlier this month with a 14pc rise in profits striking an upbeat note after a series of profit warnings in the past three years.
